WRITING.TEXT: Someone on twitter said it well, the venn diagram of people who loved PWR BTTM and people who would be willing to drop a band after sexual assault/abuse accusations came out about them is a circle.

I agree with Fantano that one of the really fucked up thing about it all is that there were people who knew what was going on, but didn't do anything about it... because how can a scene preach all of these messages yet still allow one of its figurehead to continue doing it?
Like the people who were in the know have some explaining to do.

I guess the problem for so many people is that they felt that PWR BTTM was supposed to be against all of those things. It is easy to separate the art and the artist in theory, but if what the art stands for contradicts the action of the artist then that becomes more difficult.
Like the band was supposed to be this progressive band that LGBTQ youth could rally behind, and feel safe and comfortable at their shows, so when it turned out the band was none of that, either by being an abuser or being accepting of it, then that feels like a big middle finger to the people who supported them. Like I am sure if member of a black metal band came out as gay, vegan, and pro-immigration that their core fanbase would have reacted with disgust as well... and just to be clear, I think none of those things are bad.

I mean the speaker itself actually looks pretty nice, but the turntable ruins it... like it seems like they had a good design for speakers, and they just decided to awkwardly place a turntable on top of it.
Luckily Otis Blue is easy to find
This is my fav from the album, although the whole thing is great

https://twitter.com/Foxing/status/865292218235539456
I think that tweet summed it up well

Also talking to someone who is not in your life is often easier, because feeling suicidal feels embarrassing (or it at least did for me), to admit that you're thinking of killing yourself is really hard to do, so getting to talk to someone who you don't know might be very helpful... because you don't have to deal with their judgement the same way you might have to do with people in your personal life.

Yeah when I was at my most depressed it became all consuming, there was days where I could barely think of anything besides killing myself, and I didn't want to tell my parents or friends because I was afraid that people would just tell me to deal with it or stop feeling sorry for myself.
Of course suicide is terrible, but I'd suggest anyone who think of it as selfish to either talk with someone who has been suicidal, or read literature by someone like David Foster Wallace. Because depression is ugly, it is feels embarrassing, often it feels unbearable, but it is never easy.
Yeah no, anyone who have dealt with severe depression can tell you that it is not so simple that you can just "suck it up".

This is America, nobody deserves to be treated as black man

Still really stupid though, you'd think that if anything they would have learnt from the Pepsi controversy that the dumbest way to sell us garbage food and drink is through half-assed attempts at sincerity.

Again the idea of using fallacious reasoning to call out other people's fallacies is self-contradictory, and that is what you implied when you said that calling out other people's fallacy is valid... which it isn't, there is zero merit to that way of thinking, as it rarely explains why the things they are arguing about is right or wrong.
And my point is that saying that I am wrong doesn't mean that you are wrong, we're not specifically talking about this situation, we are talking about the general ideas of pointing out fallacies. In which you are absoutely not correct by simply saying that someone else did something wrong.

Man that is so fucked up, like it is hard to know what to say in situations like this honestly... definitely gonna listen Temple of the Dog and Soundgarden this weekend though, I guess that is only way you can truly celebrate an artist's life.

Well you can't actually report entirely unbiased, you can only leave so much of your bias at the door.

Seems weird since that is a sub dedicated specifically to disregard critically thinking entirely, and to blindly worship the rhetoric of a single individual. Now obviously that isn't to say that all Trump supporters are like that, but that specific sub is definitely a cult of personality.
But that in and of itself is a logical fallacy, so it is self-contradictory, and just because someone use a logical fallacy doesn't mean that the person they are arguing against are correct.
Here is the thing though, pointing out other people's alleged fallacies is not a valid argument, so I don't have to consider it.

Yeah I don't mind people eating meat, because that is your right, but it do pisses me off when people are selectively angry at animal cruelty as long as it doesn't affect them in any way. And I am not invested enough in black metal to really care all that much, so I don't have much issue calling Wolves in The Throne Room, Krallice, Deafheaven, early Alcest, etc. black metal. Obviously I am not going to go as far as to call Young and in the Way black metal, but I am not too worried about it.
Now you might say that is ignorant, and I can't blame you, but regardless my point is that I enjoy these black metal influenced band that aren't black metal more than actual black metal, even though I have given some of those a try, and I even enjoy some of them... like Weakling or Dark Space.
But yeah I know I am not an authority by a long shot, but I don't care either way, because I'll enjoy what I'll enjoy, and I don't really feel the need to make fun of people who say wrong/stupid things about the music I enjoy, because it doesn't matter.
